intro: Gilia bicolor, commonly known as the two-color gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Mexico. It is a member of the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils. The plant produces showy, two-toned flowers that range from white to pink and purple, with a distinctive bilobed corolla. It is an annual herb that often thrives in sunny conditions and is known for its rapid growth cycle. Gilia bicolor is also valued for its ecological role, providing nectar for pollinators like bees and butterflies.
